body.p:
Being very much
engaged in writing, my dear
Father has kindly promised
to write to you on all business
matters for me, which letter
will go by the next steamer
I am writing this to
accompany the books, in
case they should arrive
before my Father's letter.
They will go thro' Mr Staker
of the Strand, but as it is
a very large parcel—we have
offered to pay part of the
freight, which proportion

Mr Staker thinks had better
be paid to Messrs C. I Hart
in Philadelphia, which I shall
feel obliged by your doing
& deducting the said sum
from the proceeds of the books
I am hourly in expectation
of my 7th number, my
printer having promised it
me to day. Should it leave
in time, I shall send it
with the other & not trouble
Mr Longman until January.
I have put up 30 copies
of each number—2.3.4—
singly & 5 & 6 together, as they
now published and 5 addition
at copies of the number one
to make up the 30 & 25 having?

been sent to you originally
you will therefore in this
parcel find 125 books, that
is if the number 7 does
not come in time. If it
should, you will find 155
instead of the 125 & the
others. I hope to send monthly.
Mr Cohen of Savannah
has kindly offered to be my
agent for 50 copies of each
number therefore I would
rather wait to see if those
sell before sending a larger
number than 30 to you. You
will also find in the parcel
a complete set of the numbers
as far as they are out,
which you will oblige me
by presenting in my name

& with my compts to Mr
Chandler, the gentleman who
reviewed my “Spirit” & the continu
ation of the Nos. for yourself, as Editor of the Oc.
I thank you much for your
kind exertions in the disposal
of my books & you will oblige
me greatly by saying the same
to Mr Hart. I thank you
also for your letter & your advice
concerning the alteration in
my style of writing & thinking
kindly meant, but impossible
either thro' conviction, or inclination
to be followed. Harshness has
never yet done good. Our God
is Love & so is His Law, (as
the Bible gives it, not as it
has often been perverted by
mistaken zealots) & I am content
to follow the same blessed
course. I do not quite know
how you could have lead?
the Perry? Family to assert

that Reuben is led to
return to his faith, thro'
the kindness of his Mother
& Sarah Levison. A more
careful reading would convince
you, that it was affliction
& the study of both religions
which saved him, from
apostacy, & caused him to
return. I feel imagi=
nation a gift from God, and
as such to be used—not checked
Believe me, there are many
hearts & dispositions which are
far more likely to be guided
by Imagination, than by a
direct reproof. How did
Nathan reprove David, was
it not by affecting his
heart & imagination, & causing

him in fact to condemn
himself. I do not ask
your praise as a reviewer
but your justice, which in
your first notice of my
Records of Israel you did not
do me. Your second notice
is very different. The great
mistake of all the Editors of
Jewish magazines, is that
the office of reviewer is an
easy one, & requires neither
much time, nor much talent
when it so imperatively ?
both, that in all English
magazines & papers—Reviewers
are a distinct branch of
literary men & their articles
of such importance, and
considered to require such

talent, as to be paid better
than for any thing else.

You must pardon one
observation only written
because, I once praised
your magazine, for a quality
which I really grieve to see
that it no longer possesses.
I mean liberality and
impartiality. You may
differ with your correspondents
& of course as an Editor have
the privilege of writing what
you please, but it is with
real regret I perceive the
very different spirit breathing?
in your later numbers to
the mild toleration pervading
your first. Perhaps this
observation is uncalled for.

but you must pardon it
when I feel that loving kindness, and
forbearance? are so very much
needed, it must be a source
of pain, to see those who
might forward the cause of love
rather retarding than advancing
it. Of such subjects we
can never think alike &
therefore perhaps I am wrong
to write of them—but I wish
you to know my sentiments
on the subject that you may
perceive how impossible it
is for my writings ever to
arrive at the standard you
require. I have written
much more at length than
I intended, & must therefore
conclude with my Parents
regards I am dear Sir
